comment: Hot nose with lots of orange and oak and a hint of vanilla.  Flavor is peppery oak, cherry, and orange.  Lingering spicy oak and a bit of char.  Just couldn't get into it.
A chocolate/ orange delight . Amazingly long finish .
Awesome release. Little funky. Almost bready.
Great nose, lots of floral, but was a little disappointed with the palate. Finish was a little too hot for my taste.

As I said in my two previous reviews (Old Forester Birthday 2015 and 2016), I just had a flight of these three bourbons.  My excitement beforehand, and my disappointment afterward, could not have been more polar opposites.  Sadly, the newest Birthday release is not the Cordelia to 2015’s Goneril or 2016’s Regan.  There just is something about this line that does not sit well with me.  Where are all the incredible flavors bursting out of the no-age-statement Old Forester 1920, which may be my favorite regular release bourbon?  Perhaps there is something about Brown-Forman’s juice that just does not benefit from aging up to the tween years, as Old Forester 1920 is probably a blend of product in the 4-8-year range and is amazing.  2017 actually takes a step in the wrong direction on the nose, with similar aromas to 2015 but with a slightly artificial caramel and glue melange that’s messing with my senses.  The palate is another wallop of oak and another desperate search for sweet notes.  If anything, bitter flavors of resin, tobacco, and shoe polish grow in strength through yet another dry finish.  I saw this at my local liquor store for $130 and am so grateful I didn’t grab it.  I just purchased two Four Roses Private Selections for less than that while in Indianapolis, which is indicative of the incredibly bad value that Birthday Bourbon has become in the current climate.
Hype machine. Save your money and time. 1920 is better.
Wow, this was a flooring pour. Creamy smooth marshmallow hot cocoa upfront, followed by creme brulee. I didn't get any of the orange that others report. A truly luxurious dram!
Sweet like cake frosting with sparkly flavor and very good body. Drank neat

Tons of fruit and floral notes on the nose. Big hints of alcohol as well. Floral notes coming through on the palate, sweet at first even the nice alcohol burn on the finish. For the rarity and price this isn’t really anything I’d go running after again
Birthday bourbon is hard to beat, but I don't think the 2017 is quite what the 2016 was.
didn't like nose but flavor was nice, would have again
Smooth, creamy marshmallow with a little cocoa spice upfront. Bit of fruit, citrus, little orange. Creme brulee right after. Little hot but very smooth.
Sweet and smooth front with a mid tongue spice. Not too alcohol front. Nice easy finish.
4.3  12-4-18.  Wow- this is really good.  Smooth start to finish - but really nice tingle at finish.  Very complex - love to find a bottle of this.
Sweet, rich, round feel. Soft, spicy fruit. Rivaled only by van winkle, though it is very different.
Great nose, sweet caramel.  Spicy for the proof. Light body, overall good but only for a modest price. 22$ for a pour
Another example of a hyped up bourbon that is losing quality as the years go on. 2.5/5

Maybe it will open up on third try. So far, first two times it is more hot than taste. I love a bold bourbon, Bookers, Stagg, or Weller are my go tops. This one I was hoping to like, but none of the rewards of the others so far. No nuance, nothing more than heat.
Birthday cake in a glass...velvet mouthfeel....chocolate notes...super smooth...warm finish
Getting a good vanilla taste. Kinda sweet while still getting the rye spice. A damn good bourbon!

So happy to have had the opportunity to try four different versions of Birthday Bourbon.  Here I can taste the Brown Forman classic taste, but not as much banana. Less sweet than the 3 others I tried.  While awesome, this was the 4th place for me.  Again, really special.
Strong coconut nose, really sweet and surprisingly short crisp finish cherry/marzipan, barn wood
Hit me on the tip of my tongue. A bit sharp for my taste.
Incredibly well sorted out. All butterscotch.
wonderfully sweet nose, which cause me to be surprised when the Spirit hit my taste buds. It was very floral almost minty, with a very nice finish.
Rich, oily mouthfeel. Sweeter on the nose - fruity, vanilla, fairly spicy and bitter on the palate, wood, tobacco. Tingly finish.
Oily mouth feel with a pastel fruit flavor that is not to my liking. This year's batch was very disappointing.
Caramel, vanilla, butterscotch, cherry, peach pit, cinnamon, brown sugar, creme brûlée, coffee cake, tobacco

Excellent dram
Nose: citrus, figs & light chocolate 
Palate: citrus again and also brown sugar/caramel 
Finish: moderate and tapers off into a spicy dryness

So I sampled this side by side with 2019 BB in what I called the "Battle of the Birthday Bourbons" after Thanksgiving Dinner.  Where 2019 had cherry and vanilla on the nose, a spicy finish, and a welcomed bit of heat, 2017 was a bit of a polar opposite.

I found the nose to have caramel and classic Old Forester green banana on the nose.  It was a bit hard for me to find but I got there.  The palate had vanilla caramels and a graham cracker crust.  I like that alot.  It was very traditional.  The finish got a bit bitter after giving some oakiness and was short......not my cup of tea for a premium once per year release.  Although some parts of this taste were really good, it fell short on others.  I actually enjoyed 1920 better than 2017 BB.  My guess is that the lack of abv robbed some of the richness.

Overall:  I prefered the 2019 over the 2017.  The 2017 had no edge, where the 2019 was interesting and more complex, 2017 was Old Forester Birthday light in my opinion.

Nose - floral- leather - chocolate - excellent nose. Want to just keep smelling 
Taste / Finish - very nice finish- smooth- warm- would like a longer burn- but excellent. - orange leather - fruit - tobacco-
Sweet nose, strong heat, notes of cherry or cough syrup
Every vintage I’ve had of this had been awesome. Need to get a bottle.
